docs.lead_paragraph: The cost of employee health coverage rose 7.7 percent this year, more than double the overall inflation rate and well ahead of the increase in the incomes of workers.

headline.main: Passing the Buck to Mom and Dad

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The lack of a dynamic and competitive health care market allows Oxford Health Plans and United Health Group to flex their market power and dictate unfair business practices that are bad for patients and doctors (''Doctors' Group Sues Two Insurers, Charging Unfair Coercion,'' news article, Sept. 21). Patients do not appear to be benefiting from the remarkable reduction in the number of competing health plans. While mergers have eroded competition among health insurers, those remaining are posting historically high profits. Meanwhile, the premiums they charge rise without an expansion of patient benefits.
docs.abstract: Letter from AMA pres Dr William G Plested calls for federal investigation of whether increased premiums and record profits posted by health plans are result of monopoly power

docs.lead_paragraph: Pharmaceutical services company AmerisourceBergen said on Monday it had agreed to buy Health Advocates for about $83 million to expand its workers' compensation business.
docs.abstract: Pharmaceutical services company AmerisourceBergen said on Monday it had agreed to buy Health Advocates for about $83 million to expand its workers' compensation business. Health Advocates, of Tampa, Fla., provides Medicare set-aside cost containment services to insurance payers primarily within the workers' compensation industry.
